TSH = [[Reasoned request/prescription and choice of diagnostic test SD-178|first-line test]] :

- Always collapsed in cases of peripheral hyperthyroidism.

- If TSH is low, second-line T4L assay to assess the severity of thyrotoxicosis.

- Determination of T3L, if T4L is normal, to look for T3 hyperthyroidism.

A distinction is made between frust or sub-clinical thyroid disease (with normal peripheral hormones) and frank thyroid disease (with elevated peripheral hormones).

properties.question: In the context of diagnosing hyperthyroidism, what is the initial diagnostic test recommended when TSH levels are low, and why is it chosen?
properties.option_a: TSH test to confirm the presence of hyperthyroidism because it is the most sensitive indicator of thyroid dysfunction.
properties.option_b: T4L assay to assess the severity of thyrotoxicosis because TSH is already low, indicating possible hyperthyroidism.
properties.option_c: T3L test to identify T3 hyperthyroidism when T4L is normal, as TSH levels are not informative in this scenario.
properties.option_d: Blood glucose test to rule out diabetes, which can sometimes present with similar symptoms to hyperthyroidism.
